text:
{"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The response addresses the core question by summarizing the likely conditions under which the injunction will stand. It explicitly covers the required elements:
(i) The response states that the arbitration clause does not oust the jurisdiction of the court, but channels disputes on the merits (Section 2).
(ii) It requires a 'Real risk the respondent will dissipate assets to frustrate enforcement of an award' (Section 3(b)).
(iii) It discusses avoiding duplication, noting the court will refuse relief if 'Singapore relief is plainly available, swift, and effective' and will avoid measures that 'pre-empt decisions the tribunal should make' (Section 3(c) and 3(d)).
(iv) It addresses urgency, stating the court typically acts where 'the tribunal cannot act effectively in time (urgency)' (Section 1) and that the injunction is more likely to stand where there is 'urgency' or 'the tribunal cannot make an order quickly enough' (Section 4).", "criterion_id": "e8d6e664-29d5-4701-aa71-9393eb1482de"}
